title: Periodic Trends & Properties
description: Explore how electron configuration determines periodic trends and chemical properties of elements
subject: Chemistry

text.introduction: The periodic table is organized based on electron configuration, which determines the chemical and physical properties of elements. Understanding periodic trends helps predict element behavior and chemical reactivity.

sections.title: Atomic Radius Trends
sections.content: Atomic radius decreases across a period due to increasing nuclear charge pulling electrons closer. Atomic radius increases down a group as new electron shells are added. These trends are explained by the balance between nuclear attraction and electron-electron repulsion.

sections.title: Ionization Energy
sections.content: Ionization energy is the energy required to remove an electron from an atom. It increases across a period due to stronger nuclear attraction and decreases down a group as electrons are farther from the nucleus. Noble gases have the highest ionization energies in their periods.

sections.title: Electronegativity
sections.content: Electronegativity measures an atom's ability to attract electrons in a chemical bond. It increases across a period and decreases down a group. Fluorine is the most electronegative element. Electronegativity differences determine bond types: ionic, polar covalent, or nonpolar covalent.

sections.title: Metallic Character
sections.content: Metallic character decreases across a period and increases down a group. Metals tend to lose electrons and form positive ions, while nonmetals gain electrons to form negative ions. Metalloids have intermediate properties and are found along the 'staircase' in the periodic table.

questions.question: How does atomic radius change as you move across a period from left to right?
questions.explanation: Atomic radius decreases across a period because increasing nuclear charge pulls electrons closer to the nucleus.

questions.question: Which element has the highest electronegativity?
questions.explanation: Fluorine has the highest electronegativity value of 4.0 on the Pauling scale.

exercises.title: Periodic Trend Analysis
exercises.instructions: Compare three elements from the same period and three from the same group. Predict their relative atomic radius, ionization energy, and electronegativity based on periodic trends.
exercises.hint: Use the periodic table position to predict trends and explain your reasoning based on electron configuration and nuclear charge.

scenarioChallenges.title: Ghana's Mineral Resources and Periodic Trends
scenarioChallenges.scenario: Ghana is rich in minerals like gold, bauxite, and manganese. Understanding periodic trends helps explain why these elements are found in specific compounds and how they can be extracted and purified.
tasks: Explain why gold is chemically unreactive based on its position in the periodic table
Describe how aluminum's properties make it valuable despite being the most abundant metal in Ghana's bauxite
Analyze manganese's variable oxidation states using periodic trends
learningObjectives: Apply periodic trends to explain mineral properties
Understand the connection between electron configuration and economic value
Relate chemistry to Ghana's mining industry
scenarioChallenges.ghanaContext: Ghana's economy heavily depends on mineral exports, making understanding of elemental properties crucial for the mining and processing industries.
